qas.question: What did Avicenna start an inquiry into?

context: Following <a2_0><b5_0><b11_0>al-Farabi<b11_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>'s lead, Avicenna initiated a full-fledged inquiry into <a0_0><b9_0>the question of being<b9_0/><a0_0/>, in which he distinguished between <a1_0><a4_0><b6_0><b10_0><b13_0>essence<b13_0/><a4_0/> (<b7_0>Mahiat<b7_0/>) and existence (<a3_0><b12_0>Wujud<b12_0/><a3_0/>)<b10_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/>. He argued that the fact of existence can not be inferred from or accounted for by the essence of existing things, and that form and matter by themselves cannot interact and originate the movement of the universe or the progressive actualization of existing things. Existence must, therefore, be due to an agent-cause that necessitates, imparts, gives, or adds existence to an essence. To do so, <b8_0>the cause<b8_0/> must be an existing thing and coexist with its effect.
